Literature Review: Induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) have revolutionized the field of disease modeling and regenerative medicine since their discovery by Takahashi and Yamanaka in 2006. These cells, derived from adult somatic cells through the introduction of specific transcription factors, possess the ability to differentiate into various cell types, offering unprecedented opportunities to study human diseases in vitro and develop novel therapeutic approaches. The utility of iPSCs in disease biology stems from their capacity to recapitulate complex human phenotypes that are often challenging to model in animals or immortalized cell lines. This advantage is particularly evident in the study of genetic disorders, where patient-specific iPSCs can be generated to investigate disease mechanisms at a cellular level. For instance, Dimos et al. demonstrated the successful generation of motor neurons from iPSCs derived from patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), providing a valuable tool for understanding the pathogenesis of this neurodegenerative disorder. In the field of musculoskeletal research, iPSCs have shown great promise in modeling various disorders. Yamashita et al. utilized iPSCs to generate chondrocytes from patients with skeletal dysplasia, revealing novel insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying cartilage formation and disease progression. Similarly, Chal et al. developed a protocol for efficient differentiation of iPSCs into functional skeletal muscle, opening new avenues for studying muscular dystrophies and other muscle-related disorders. Pulmonary diseases have also benefited from iPSC technology. Huang et al. generated lung epithelial cells from iPSCs derived from patients with cystic fibrosis, demonstrating the potential of these cells to model lung diseases and screen for therapeutic compounds. Furthermore, Ghaedi et al. successfully differentiated iPSCs into functional alveolar epithelial type II cells, providing a valuable tool for studying lung development and respiratory disorders. The application of iPSCs in neurological research has been particularly impactful. Soldner et al. used iPSCs to model Parkinson's disease, generating dopaminergic neurons that exhibited disease-specific phenotypes. This approach has since been extended to other neurological disorders, including Alzheimer's disease and schizophrenia, offering new insights into the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying these complex conditions. Cardiac research has also been transformed by iPSC technology. Moretti et al. demonstrated the utility of iPSCs in modeling long QT syndrome, a cardiac arrhythmia disorder, by generating patient-specific cardiomyocytes that recapitulated the electrophysiological abnormalities characteristic of the disease. This approach has been widely adopted for studying various inherited cardiac disorders and for drug screening purposes. One of the most exciting developments in iPSC research is the emergence of organoid models. These three-dimensional structures, derived from iPSCs, mimic the cellular organization and function of specific organs or tissues. Lancaster et al. pioneered the development of cerebral organoids, which have since been used to study neurodevelopmental disorders and brain tumors. Similarly, Takebe et al. generated liver organoids from iPSCs, demonstrating their potential for modeling liver diseases and drug toxicity studies. Despite the numerous advantages of iPSCs in disease modeling, several challenges remain. The variability in differentiation efficiency and the potential for genetic and epigenetic aberrations during reprogramming and long-term culture can impact the reliability and reproducibility of iPSC-based models. Additionally, the current iPSC-derived cells often represent immature or fetal-like phenotypes, which may not fully recapitulate adult disease states. To address these limitations, researchers are developing advanced differentiation protocols and employing genome editing techniques to enhance the fidelity of iPSC-based disease models. For instance, Shi et al. utilized CRISPR-Cas9 technology to correct disease-causing mutations in patient-derived iPSCs, demonstrating the potential for combining gene editing with iPSC technology for disease modeling and therapeutic development. In conclusion, iPSCs have emerged as a powerful tool for studying human disease biology and drug discovery. Their ability to generate patient-specific cell types and organoids offers unprecedented opportunities to investigate disease mechanisms, screen for therapeutic compounds, and develop personalized medicine approaches. As the field continues to advance, addressing the current limitations and refining differentiation protocols will further enhance the utility of iPSCs in both basic and translational research, paving the way for novel insights into human biology and the development of innovative therapies for a wide range of diseases.
